answer_html: \(\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} +s \begin{bmatrix} -4\\ -1\\ 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} +t \begin{bmatrix} -5\\ -3\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.\) There are an infinite number of solutions.
answer_latex:
$\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+s
\begin{bmatrix}
-4\\
-1\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+t
\begin{bmatrix}
-5\\
-3\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.$ There are an infinite number of solutions.
hints_html: Recall that if the matrix has a row of zeros then the corresponding value in the augmented part of the matrix must be zero or there is no solution.
hints_latex:
Recall that if the matrix has a row of zeros then the corresponding
value in the augmented part of the matrix must be zero or there is no
solution.
hints_raw: Recall that if the matrix has a row of zeros then the corresponding value in the augmented part of the matrix must be zero or there is no solution.
question: B 04 (c)
sols_html:
From the matrix,

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cccc}1 & 0 & 4 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array}\right.\left| \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \\ 0 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

we see that the last row is all zeros (including the augmented part) and so we have a free parameter. Since there are more columns than rows to this matrix (the matrix is rank deficient) then there is a second free parameter. Let the free parameters be x_3 and x_4. Then from the second row we have

\[\begin{aligned} x_2+x_3+3x_4&=2\\ x_2&=2-x_3-3x_4\end{aligned}\]

and from the first row we have

\[\begin{aligned} x_1+4x_3+5x_4&=1\\ x_1&=1-4x_3-5x_4.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we have two null vectors

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} -4\\ -1\\ 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} -5\\ -3\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

as well as a particular solution

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

so that the solution is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} +s \begin{bmatrix} -4\\ -1\\ 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} +t \begin{bmatrix} -5\\ -3\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

There are an infinite number of solutions.
sols_raw:
From the matrix,

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cccc}1 & 0 & 4 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array}\right. \left| \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \\ 0 \end{array}\right]
</math>

we see that the last row is all zeros (including the augmented part) and so we have a free parameter.  Since there are more columns than rows to this matrix (the matrix is rank deficient) then there is a second free parameter.  Let the free parameters be x_3 and x_4.  Then from the second row we have

:<math>
\begin{align}
x_2+x_3+3x_4&=2\\
x_2&=2-x_3-3x_4
\end{align}
</math>

and from the first row we have

:<math>
\begin{align}
x_1+4x_3+5x_4&=1\\
x_1&=1-4x_3-5x_4.
\end{align}
</math>

Therefore we have two null vectors

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
-4\\
-1\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

and

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
-5\\
-3\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

as well as a particular solution

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

so that the solution is

:<math>
\mathbf{x}=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+s
\begin{bmatrix}
-4\\
-1\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+t
\begin{bmatrix}
-5\\
-3\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

There are an infinite number of solutions.
statement_html:
The augmented matrix below for a linear system is put in reduced row echelon form with row operations. Write one of the following:

  • the solution if it is unique

  • all solutions if there are more than one

  • state that there are no solutions.

(c)

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cccc}1 & 0 & 4 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array}\right.\left| \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \\ 0 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
The augmented matrix below for a linear system is put in reduced row echelon form with row operations. Write one of the following:
* the solution if it is unique
* all solutions if there are more than one
* state that there are no solutions.

'''(c)'''
:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cccc}1 & 0 & 4 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array}\right. \left| \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \\ 0 \end{array}\right]
</math>
